creditline: Gift of Ruth and Bruce Dayton
department: Chinese, South and Southeast Asian Art
description: This book cover originally protected the Buddhist manuscript known as 'Prajnaparamitasutra' (The Perfection of Wisdom); three seated figures across central panel--central figure is 'Prajnaparamita'; two of her four hands hold a 'vajra' and a sutra; the other two are in the 'abhaya' and 'dyana' positions; Padmapani stands to her right and Green Tara to her left; six smaller Buddhas are seated across the bottom of the border and four are seated across the top; foliate forms and mythological beasts are between the Buddhas
text: Tantric practitioners rely on sacred manuscripts to impart the teachings of a deity. In this case, the manuscript, which is a philosophical work on the nature of prajna (wisdom), includes the representation of the deity Prajnaparamita, who personifies the text. She is depicted in the center of the elaborately carved wooden cover holding a book and vajra (thunderbolt) in her upper hands, flanked by Green Tārā on her left and Avalokiteshvara on her right. The manuscript would have been protected by two wooden covers and wrapped in cloth. Considered to be a divine object, it was worshipped with flowers, incense, and unguents, much like the worship of a deity in a shrine. Practitioners believe that the book itself possesses sacred power.
title: Prajnaparamita book cover
